unnormalised: The Ministry of Consumer Affairs has issued new guidelines regarding the standardization of measurements in culinary recipes. The directive, effective from 01/01/2025, aims to address inconsistencies in ingredient quantities, which often lead to confusion among home cooks and professional chefs alike. The primary concern revolves around the varied interpretations of common units such as "a pinch," "a cup," and "a spoon," which can significantly impact the final outcome of a dish.
normalised: The Ministry of Consumer Affairs has issued new guidelines regarding the standardization of measurements in culinary recipes. The directive, effective from first january two thousand and twenty five, aims to address inconsistencies in ingredient quantities, which often lead to confusion among home cooks and professional chefs alike. The primary concern revolves around the varied interpretations of common units such as "a pinch," "a cup," and "a spoon," which can significantly impact the final outcome of a dish.

unnormalised: As per the new regulation, all publicly available recipes, including those in cookbooks, online platforms, and culinary programs, must adhere to the International System of Units (SI). This means using precise measurements like grams (g) for solids, milliliters (ml) for liquids, and specific temperature readings in degrees Celsius (°C). Recipes currently using imperial units, such as ounces (oz) and fluid ounces (fl oz), will need to provide metric equivalents alongside.
normalised: As per the new regulation, all publicly available recipes, including those in cookbooks, online platforms, and culinary programs, must adhere to the International System of Units (S-I). This means using precise measurements like grams (g) for solids, milliliters (ml) for liquids, and specific temperature readings in degrees Celsius (°C). Recipes currently using imperial units, such as ounces (oz) and fluid ounces (fl oz), will need to provide metric equivalents alongside.

unnormalised: The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) will oversee the implementation of these guidelines, conducting audits and workshops to educate stakeholders. Penalties for non-compliance may include fines up to Rs. 50,000 and potential removal of non-compliant recipes from circulation. An advisory committee consisting of renowned chefs and nutritionists, including Chef Sanjeev Kapoor and Dr. Priya Sharma, has been formed to provide expert guidance on the practical aspects of this transition.

unnormalised: The initiative is expected to benefit both consumers and the food industry. Standardized measurements will ensure consistent results, reduce food waste, and promote accurate nutritional information. The ministry anticipates that this move will elevate the quality of Indian cuisine and enhance the overall culinary experience for everyone.
